title: Design approval state machine (lifecycle transitions)
description:
Define and implement the approval lifecycle state machine governing how approval requests transition through their lifecycle.

States: open → assigned → under_review → decided (approved | denied | changes_requested) → executed | rolled_back | expired

Requirements:
- Formal state machine with explicit transition guards (e.g., cannot approve if SoD violation, cannot transition to executed without all required approvals)
- Support for composite decisions: N-of-M approvals, sequential approval chains, specialist-required gates
- "Request changes" as a first-class state (blocks progress until addressed, like GitHub PR reviews)
- Escalation transitions: handoff to another approver ("needs review by X")
- Timeout/SLA-driven transitions (auto-escalate, auto-expire)
- Each transition produces a domain event (ApprovalOpened, ApprovalAssigned, DecisionRecorded, ApprovalExecuted, etc.)
- Transitions must be deterministic and auditable

title: API versioning strategy — compatibility rules + deprecation policy
description:
The OpenAPI v1 contract is positioned as source of truth and is "defined and evolving." For tooling (docs generation, client generation, testing) to work smoothly, the project needs explicit compatibility rules and deprecation policy.

Define:
- What constitutes a breaking change vs. backward-compatible evolution
- Versioning scheme for API, event schemas, and deployment charts
- CI checks that enforce compatibility (e.g., spectral lint, breaking-change detection on OpenAPI diffs)
- Deprecation timeline and communication mechanism
- How clients discover supported versions

This prevents "the API changed and all clients broke" as Portarium reaches real consumers.

title: PDB validation + maintenance runbook
description:

title: Implement separation of duties and maker-checker enforcement
description:
Implement the governance primitives that control who is eligible to approve what, enforcing separation of duties at the domain/application layer.

Patterns to support:
- Maker-checker: requestor ≠ approver (prevent self-approval)
- N-of-M approvals: require N approvals from a pool of M eligible approvers for high-risk actions
- Specialist approval: require specific role/team approval based on what is changing (e.g., "data-platform team must approve SQL changes", analogous to GitHub CODEOWNERS / file-pattern reviewers)
- Role/authority mapping: clear mapping of who can approve what, queryable at approval-creation time

Implementation:
- Policy inputs: approval payload kind, risk score, affected resources, resource ownership, data classification
- Approver eligibility resolver: given payload + policy, return eligible approvers and why each is required
- SoD violation detector: prevent bypass by alternate channels (embedded approvals must enforce same rules)
- Durable identity attribution: approver identity must be cryptographically bound to decision

The UI must always expose: who is eligible to approve, why this approver is required, and what rule/policy is being satisfied or violated.

title: Security: structured auth event logging for 401/403/429 responses
description:

(2) In respondProblem(), optionally accept a log callback; call it for 401/403/429 responses.
(3) Use process.stderr.write() with a JSON-structured log line: { level: 'warn', event: 'auth_failure'|'rate_limit', ... }.
(4) Add unit tests that confirm the log output on 401 and 403.

Acceptance criteria: 401/403/429 responses emit a structured log line; log line never contains the Authorization header value; tests confirm the logging.

title: Design immutable approval payload domain model
description:
Define the core domain types for the approval payload — the immutable snapshot of "what was proposed" at the moment the approval request was created. This is the foundational contract the entire approval system builds on.

Must include:
- ApprovalRequest aggregate with immutable payload (diffs, previews, simulation outputs, policy evaluation at request time)
- ApprovalState value object (mutable): assignment, queue status, decisions, comments, escalation

- Evidence attachment references (by hash/ID, not inline content)
- Branded domain primitives: ApprovalId, PayloadHash, DecisionId, etc.

- Domain code in src/domain/ — zero external dependencies
- Payload must be content-addressable (hash-verified) so approvers know they approved exactly what executed
- Support for multi-decision workflows (N-of-M, sequential approvals)

description:
Epic to systematically integrate findings from docs/research/report-27.md — a critical analysis of Portarium's testing and verification posture. Rated P0 because the codebase is described as 'effectively untested' with critical business logic having zero automated coverage.

**Report summary**: Portarium has strong static checks (TypeScript, ESLint, Prettier, spellcheck, dependency audits) in CI but almost no unit or integration tests for the actual business logic. The pack resolver, SOD constraint evaluation, rate-limiter, event publishers, and domain invariants all lack automated coverage. **Scope**: Full read → validate → implement cycle. The testing epic is the highest priority because every other improvement area (security hardening, architectural refactors, data layer changes) requires a test suite to be safe to do.

**Key themes from the report**:
- Unit test gaps: pack resolver (core business logic), SOD (segregation of duties) constraint evaluator, workspace-scoped rate-limiter, CloudEvent publishers, domain entity invariants
- Integration test gaps: no adapter integration tests against real Postgres, no Temporal workflow integration tests, no NATS publish/subscribe integration tests
- E2E test gaps: no automated browser tests for Cockpit flows, no CLI smoke tests
- Coverage targets: report recommends 70-80% branch coverage as a realistic initial target with CI enforcement
- Test architecture: report recommends DI refactors to make units more isolatable, plus a factory/builder pattern for test fixtures
- In-memory store risk: several components use in-memory stores that are never tested in distributed/multi-instance scenarios
- CI gaps: no coverage reporting, no coverage threshold gate, no test-result artifact upload

**Specific modules called out by report**:
- src/domain/ pack resolver — zero tests
- src/domain/ SOD evaluator — zero tests
- src/application/ workflow orchestration — zero tests
- src/infrastructure/ rate-limiter — zero tests
- src/infrastructure/ event publishers — zero tests
- Temporal worker loop — no integration tests

**Exit criteria**: Coverage gate at ≥70% branch coverage enforced in CI; all six called-out modules have unit test suites; at least one integration test suite per infrastructure adapter; E2E smoke test covers happy-path governed run.

title: Approval Workflows — Universal Decision Surface
description:
Portarium's governance-first architecture makes approvals the universal choke-point where humans reassert intent, accountability, and risk ownership. This epic covers the full approval system: a stable "approval shell" (queues, identity, policy context, decision capture, evidence) plus a pluggable "payload presentation" layer (diffs, previews, simulations, side-by-side comparisons, attachments, model explanations).

Key product thesis: the approvals experience is Portarium's "single pane of accountability" — a UX container supporting many payload types while staying consistent, fast, safe, and auditable.

Design constraints (non-negotiable):
- Approvals bind to immutable snapshots (the thing approved cannot silently change)
- Custom views are deterministic renderings of evidence, not arbitrary agent-defined UI
- Untrusted content is sanitised and constrained (CSP + encoding)
- Policy is explainable: UI shows why a policy triggered, in human terms
- Evidence-first: every run produces audit-worthy evidence

Reference domains: data ops, marketing assets, finance, software changes, robotic/agentic actions, demo generation.

title: Define SLIs/SLOs + error budget policy
description:
You cannot manage a service without defining what matters (SLIs), the target (SLOs), and what you do when you breach them. Existing beads mention "SLO dashboards + alerting" and "automated rollback on SLO breach" but skip the prerequisite: choosing SLIs, defining SLO windows, and adopting an error budget policy.

Without explicit SLOs, rollbacks devolve into ad hoc judgement calls.

Deliverables:
- SLI definitions for control plane (availability, latency p50/p95/p99, error rate)
- SLI definitions for worker (task completion rate, latency, retry rate)
- SLO targets with measurement windows (rolling 28-day, etc.)
- Error budget policy: what happens when budget is exhausted (freeze releases? reliability sprint?)
- Link SLOs to progressive delivery actions (canary promotion/rollback thresholds)

This is a hidden dependency — dashboards and alerts without SLO definitions are meaningless.

title: Security: replace in-memory rate-limiter with Redis-backed distributed store
description:
From report-29 (bead-y0ac) and report-31 (bead-8lup). Blocked by bead-16hd (validate task).

The current rate-limiter is in-memory per workspace. This is a P0 security and availability risk: pod restarts reset all rate-limit counters, and multi-replica deployments have completely independent counters — meaning an attacker can bypass rate limits by simply hitting different pods.

Scope:

(1) Confirm Redis availability — check if Redis is already in the docker-compose/Helm stack for any other purpose (caching, queue). If it is, the rate-limiter migration is a small lift.

(2) Abstract the rate-limiter behind a port interface — the rate-limiter should implement a RateLimiterPort interface with a single method: check(workspaceId, key, limit, windowSeconds): Promise<{allowed: boolean, remaining: number, resetAt: Date}>. The current in-memory implementation becomes InMemoryRateLimiter (test/dev only). The new production implementation is RedisRateLimiter using atomic INCR + EXPIRE commands (or a sliding window log with ZADD/ZRANGEBYSCORE).

(3) Implement RedisRateLimiter — use Redis INCR with EXPIRE for fixed-window, or a sorted-set sliding window for more accurate limiting. Wrap in a try/catch with fallback to allow (fail-open) with alerting, so a Redis outage doesn't block all traffic.

(4) Registration and config — register RedisRateLimiter in production bootstrap; InMemoryRateLimiter in test/dev bootstrap. Configure via env vars: RATE_LIMIT_STORE=redis|memory, REDIS_URL, rate limits per workspace tier.

(5) Tests — unit test both implementations against their respective stores; integration test that two concurrent requests to different app instances share the same counter.

Acceptance criteria: in-memory rate-limiter removed from production path; Redis rate-limiter deployed and tested; fail-open behaviour verified; multi-instance counter sharing verified.
close_reason: Redis-backed distributed rate-limit store implemented with 15 tests; RATE_LIMIT_STORE=redis|memory env var; docker-compose rate-limiting profile added

title: Health probe semantics spec — liveness vs readiness vs backing stores
description:

Define:
- What "ready" means for control plane (DB connected? Event stream reachable? Auth provider reachable?)

title: Build renderer registry for domain-specific approval views
description:
Implement the renderer registry model that selects the best visual renderer for a given approval payload kind, with graceful fallback to generic rendering.

Architecture:
- Each approval payload has a kind (or contentType) and a set of evidence attachments/blocks
- Cockpit UI selects the best renderer available for that kind
- Fallback to generic renderer (effects list + attachments) when no specialised renderer exists

Renderer sources:
- First-party vertical packs: built into Portarium for core domains (data ops, marketing, finance, software, agentic actions)
- Tenant-approved extensions: tenant admin can enable curated renderers from a registry
- Agent-authored layouts: agents can choose which blocks to include and order them, but only from allow-listed block types

Renderers to build (initial set):
- Data operation renderer: table-level diff, record-level sample, JSON Patch, dry-run results
- Marketing asset renderer: side-by-side content comparison (before/after), asset preview (image/video)
- Finance renderer: amounts, accounts, payees, thresholds, invoices, approval chain
- Agent/robot action renderer: intent, tools/actions list, simulation output, expected writes
- Generic renderer: fallback for unknown payload kinds

Each renderer is a React component consuming typed block data — no access to raw approval internals.

title: Implement policy evaluation pipeline with explainability
description:
Build the policy-as-code evaluation pipeline that determines what approval gates apply to a given request, and provides human-readable explanations of why.

Requirements:
- Policy engine that evaluates structured approval inputs (payload kind, risk tags, resource ownership, data classification, blast radius)
- Produces structured results: pass / fail / needs_human, per-policy
- Explainability hooks: human-readable traces explaining why a policy triggered, linked to triggering evidence
- Responsibility mappings: ownership, required specialist approvers derived from policy
- Policy evaluation snapshot captured at approval-creation time (immutable, part of approval record)

Design considerations:
- Evaluate policies over structured inputs (Rego-like model or similar)
- Policies must be authorable/versionable (policy-as-code)
- UI must render: policy results, traces/explanations, links to inputs (diff blocks, effects blocks), responsibility mappings
- Goal: no "approvals as vibes" — every approval decision is grounded in policy + evidence

description:
From report-21 (bead-6i3j). Blocked by bead-8k55 (validate task).

Zero automated tests exist for the data layer. This is critical because schema migrations and query logic are hardest to recover from in production.

Scope: (1) Migration tests — every migration runs forward cleanly on fresh Postgres; every migration has working rollback; running migrations twice is idempotent; final schema matches expected structure. (2) Repository unit tests — happy path (insert, find, update, delete) for every repo class; not-found cases return DomainNotFoundError not crash; pagination (offset/limit) applied correctly; transactions roll back on failure. (3) Query correctness — list queries return correct results with seed data; filters compose correctly; workspace isolation enforced (workspace A queries never return workspace B data). title: AI/ML: responsible AI foundations — PII guardrails, audit logging, and explainability for AI-assisted approvals

title: Architecture: add caching layer for hot policy/config reads (Redis or in-process TTL cache)
description: From report-23 bead-4m9a. Blocked by bead-0js5 (validate task). The control plane has no caching — every request to evaluate a policy or load workspace config hits Postgres and OpenFGA. Under load this will be a bottleneck. Scope: (1) Identify the 3-5 hottest read paths: workspace config, OpenFGA policy check results, pack definitions, workspace role lookups. (2) Design a CachePort interface: get(key): Promise<T | null>; set(key, value, ttlSeconds): Promise<void>; invalidate(key): Promise<void>; invalidatePattern(pattern): Promise<void>. (3) Implement RedisCacheAdapter and InMemoryTTLCacheAdapter (for dev/test). (4) Wrap the hot read paths with cache-aside pattern: check cache first; on miss, fetch from source and populate cache with appropriate TTL. (5) Add cache invalidation on write: when workspace config changes, invalidate the relevant cache keys. (6) Add cache hit/miss metrics to OTel (cache.hits, cache.misses counters). (7) Document TTL choices in a cache-strategy section in an ADR. Acceptance criteria: hot reads served from cache on repeat calls; cache invalidation on mutation; metrics instrumented; unit tests for both cache adapters; integration test confirming cache invalidation on write.

(2) Indexes — B-tree on all WHERE-clause columns; composite indexes for multi-column hot-path filters; partial indexes where appropriate. (3) Pagination — every list query method accepts LIMIT and OFFSET; HTTP endpoints expose page/pageSize; total count returned for UI pagination controls. (4) JSON schema validation — add CHECK constraint or application-layer schema validation on domain_documents JSON column before insert/update. (5) Remove SELECT * — replace with explicit column lists in all queries to prevent surprise breakage from schema changes.

Acceptance criteria: all cross-table refs have FK constraints; all WHERE columns have indexes; all list queries paginate; no SELECT * anywhere; CI data layer tests (parallel bead) confirm all above.

title: Data layer: make Postgres pool sizing and timeout configuration explicit
description: From report-21 (bead-6i3j). NodePostgresSqlClient (src/infrastructure/postgresql/node-postgres-sql-client.ts) instantiates pg.Pool with only a connection string, relying on pg defaults (max=10, idleTimeoutMillis=10000, connectionTimeoutMillis=0). These defaults are not appropriate for all production workloads and the zero connectionTimeoutMillis can cause indefinite hangs under pool exhaustion. Scope: (1) Add explicit pool config parameters to NodePostgresSqlClientConfig: maxConnections, idleTimeoutMs, connectionTimeoutMs, statementTimeoutMs. (2) Map these from env vars: PORTARIUM_DB_POOL_MAX, PORTARIUM_DB_POOL_IDLE_TIMEOUT_MS, PORTARIUM_DB_CONNECTION_TIMEOUT_MS, PORTARIUM_DB_STATEMENT_TIMEOUT_MS. (3) Set sensible non-zero defaults (e.g., connectionTimeoutMs=5000, statementTimeoutMs=30000). (4) Add tests asserting config is passed through to pool. Acceptance criteria: pool config is explicit and env-configurable; zero connectionTimeoutMs is not the default; tests confirm config propagation.

(b) Audit all store adapter list methods; replace fetch+filter patterns with SQL WHERE predicates and ORDER BY. (c) Ensure all list endpoints have LIMIT applied at SQL level (no unbounded full scans). (d) Add benchmarks / tests asserting query count. Acceptance criteria: no N+1 in workforce listing; all list queries have SQL-level limits; unit tests verify query patterns.

title: Security: remove or hard-gate dev-mode static bearer token; harden JWT validation
description:
From report-29 (bead-y0ac). Blocked by bead-16hd (validate task). This is a P0 security hardening task.

The control plane has a dev-mode static bearer token fallback. This must never be reachable in non-local environments. JWT validation may also have gaps (alg:none, audience/issuer not validated).

Scope:

(1) Static bearer token — find every code path that accepts a static token; add a hard env-gate (must be explicitly enabled via ENABLE_DEV_AUTH=true, not just the absence of NODE_ENV=production); add startup assertion that fails the process if ENABLE_DEV_AUTH is set and NODE_ENV is not 'development' or 'test'; add a CI test that confirms the API returns 401 with a valid-looking token when dev auth is disabled.

(2) JWT validation hardening — find the JWT verify call; ensure algorithms array explicitly lists only allowed algorithms and never includes 'none'; validate audience claim against AUTH_AUDIENCE config; validate issuer claim against AUTH_ISSUER config; ensure nbf and exp are enforced (most JWT libraries do this by default but verify explicitly).

(3) Token revocation — check if logout/revocation is supported; if tokens are long-lived JWTs with no revocation, document the risk and consider short expiry + refresh token pattern.

(4) Auth rejection test suite — add tests for: missing Authorization header returns 401; malformed token returns 401; expired token returns 401; wrong audience returns 401; wrong issuer returns 401; valid token for wrong workspace returns 403.

Acceptance criteria: static token path requires explicit ENABLE_DEV_AUTH=true; process fails to start if ENABLE_DEV_AUTH and NODE_ENV != development/test; all JWT validation properties verified in unit tests; auth rejection test suite passes in CI.
close_reason: ENABLE_DEV_AUTH env gate + fatal startup assert + JWT audience/issuer/alg:none tests implemented

title: Data layer: add unit-of-work / withTransaction abstraction to SqlClient
description: From report-21 (bead-6i3j). SqlClient (src/infrastructure/postgresql/sql-client.ts) exposes only a query() method — no transaction boundary abstraction. This prevents atomically combining: (1) state writes to domain_documents or relational projections with (2) outbox row inserts, which is required for Transactional Outbox correctness. Without it, partial failures leave state written but event not enqueued, or vice versa. Scope: (a) Add withTransaction(fn: (txClient: SqlClient) => Promise<T>): Promise<T> to the SqlClient interface and NodePostgresSqlClient implementation (using pg.PoolClient + BEGIN/COMMIT/ROLLBACK). (b) Create TxSqlClient wrapper that ensures all queries in fn run within one connection/transaction. (c) Enforce in multi-write use-cases (run start + outbox, approval + outbox). (d) Add unit tests for transaction rollback on error and commit on success. (e) Update postgres-eventing.ts outbox enqueue to accept a tx client. Acceptance criteria: multi-write operations are atomic; failure in any step rolls back the entire transaction; tests prove rollback behaviour.
close_reason: Implemented withTransaction on SqlClient interface + NodePostgresSqlClient (BEGIN/COMMIT/ROLLBACK, nested tx reuses connection, pool injectable). Updated InMemorySqlClient + 4 test doubles. 6 new unit tests. 2937 tests pass.

title: LLM security controls — output validation, prompt-injection resistance, agency boundaries
description: OWASP Top 10 for LLM Applications: prompt injection, insecure output handling, sensitive info disclosure, excessive agency, overreliance. Deliverables: output validation/sanitisation before cockpit rendering, prompt-injection resistance in RAG flows, hard agency boundaries (AI advisor recommend-only, never auto-approve), cross-workspace data leak prevention in AI responses, overreliance guardrails (low-confidence indicators), adversarial test suite.

title: Cockpit: add error boundaries, loading states, and empty states across all async views
description: From report-24 bead-vox6. Blocked by bead-sy6l (validate task). Cockpit has no React error boundaries, no loading indicators on async actions, and errors silently fail. This violates Nielsen heuristic 1 (visibility of system status) and heuristic 9 (help users recover from errors). Scope: (1) Add a top-level ErrorBoundary wrapping the entire app; add per-section ErrorBoundaries so a broken widget doesn't crash the whole page; each boundary shows a user-friendly error card with a retry button and error code. (2) Identify every mutation (form submit, approval button, reject button, any action that calls the API); add loading state to the trigger (disabled + spinner) and success/failure feedback (toast or inline). (3) Identify every page/section that fetches data on mount; add skeleton loading component during fetch; add empty-state component when data returns empty; add error-state component when fetch fails with retry option. (4) Remove any silent error swallowing (catch blocks that do nothing). Acceptance criteria: no unhandled errors crash the page silently; every async action has loading + success/error feedback; every data-fetching view has skeleton + empty + error states; error boundaries in CI component tests.

title: CI-to-cloud OIDC trust policy hardening
description:
The infra plan includes OIDC federation for CI (GitHub Actions → cloud). Mis-scoped trust policies and missing claim constraints are frequent sources of pipeline fragility or over-privilege.

Deliverables:
- OIDC trust policy review: verify claim constraints (repo, branch, environment, workflow)
- Principle of least privilege for CI identity
- Document the trust boundary: what can a compromised CI workflow access?
- Test: verify workflow from a different branch/repo/org is rejected

title: Build approval shell UI (stable container component)
description:
Implement the stable, consistent approval container UI that wraps all approval types. This is the "approval shell" — the consistent frame that every approval renders within, regardless of payload kind.

The shell must always answer at a glance:
- What is being approved? (type + short title + system of record)
- What will happen if approved? (high-level effects summary)
- Who is asking and why? (requestor/agent + objective)
- How risky is it? (risk score + why + blast radius indicator)
- What policy gates apply? (SoD/N-of-M/specialist requirements)
- What is the deadline? (SLA / operational urgency)
- What evidence exists? (attachments, diffs, previews, prior runs)

UX requirements:
- Card-based layout suitable for both list view and detail view
- Consistent action bar: Approve / Request Changes / Deny (with rationale input for negative outcomes)
- Prior decisions visible (who else has reviewed, what they decided)
- Escalation action: "needs review by X" handoff
- Responsive: works in cockpit sidebar, full-page, and embedded contexts
- Shell renders the selected domain renderer (from renderer registry) in its content area

title: Research Integration: Cockpit UI/UX & HCI (report-24)
description:
Epic to systematically integrate findings from docs/research/report-24.md — a deep HCI and code quality review of the Cockpit UI against Nielsen heuristics, WCAG, ISO 9241, and engineering best practices.

**Report summary**: Cockpit has a solid card-based foundation with keyboard-first interactions and clear content hierarchy, but suffers from critical UX and code quality gaps: missing action feedback (no spinners or confirmation dialogs), inconsistent navigation and visual patterns, inadequate accessibility (no skip-link, missing ARIA labels, colour-reliant status badges), a 750+ line TriageCard component, hardcoded demo data in production UI, and no error boundaries or loading states.

**Scope**: Full read → validate → implement cycle covering all sections: UX design artefacts, HCI theory alignment, user flows, accessibility, error handling, performance/scalability, maintainability, and the prioritised remediation roadmap.

**Key themes from the report**:
- Interaction feedback: no loading spinners, no confirmation modals for destructive actions, no optimistic UI updates — violates Nielsen heuristic #1 (visibility of system status)
- Navigation consistency: inconsistent breadcrumb usage, some pages orphaned from main nav, back-button behaviour unreliable
- Accessibility: no skip-navigation link, missing aria-label on icon buttons, status badges convey meaning purely through colour (WCAG 1.4.1 failure), no keyboard trap management in modals
- Component architecture: TriageCard is 750+ lines — needs decomposition into focused sub-components with clear prop contracts
- Hardcoded demo data: production UI contains demo/seed data paths that should never ship (security and trust risk)
- Error handling: no React error boundaries, no empty-state components, async errors silently fail
- Performance: no virtualisation on long lists, no code-splitting on heavy routes

**Exit criteria**: All child beads closed or explicitly deferred; Cockpit passes a basic WCAG AA automated audit (axe-core); TriageCard is decomposed; no hardcoded demo data paths remain.

title: RAG tenancy isolation model — workspace-scoped vector + graph retrieval
description: Vector and graph backends for RAG need explicit tenancy and auth models matching workspace boundaries. Decide: vector DB shards-per-workspace (stronger isolation) vs filters-per-workspace (simpler, leakage risk). Graph DB: multi-database per workspace vs shared graph with row-level security. Define authorisation unit for retrieval. Enforce isolation in storage layer, not only HTTP. Test: cross-workspace query must never return another workspace data.

title: Research Integration: Security (report-29)
description:
Epic to systematically integrate findings from docs/research/report-29.md — a security audit of Portarium's identity and access management, secrets and cryptography, network and deployment security, and development/QA security practices. Rated P0.

**Report summary**: The control plane uses JWTs (JWKS URI) with a dev-mode static bearer token fallback, workspace-scoped RBAC with optional OpenFGA integration, HashiCorp Vault for credential secrets, and in-memory per-workspace rate limiting. Parameterised SQL queries and structured error responses are present. However, critical gaps exist across all four security domains.

**Scope**: Full read → validate → implement cycle. Security findings must be triaged against current state before acting — some may have been addressed. Any finding that exposes credentials, authentication bypass, or privilege escalation is P0 and must be addressed before the next release.

**Key themes from the report**:

### Identity and Access Management
- Dev-mode static bearer token: the fallback static token path must not be reachable in any non-local environment; needs env-gate or removal
- JWT validation gaps: check that 'alg: none' is rejected, that audience and issuer claims are validated, that token expiry is enforced
- OpenFGA integration: optional but inconsistently applied — workspaces without OpenFGA may have weaker access control than intended; needs audit
- Role escalation surface: no tests verifying that workspace-role boundaries cannot be crossed via API

### Secrets and Cryptography
- Vault credential store: verify that credentials are rotated, that lease expiry is handled gracefully, and that fallback-on-Vault-unavailable does not expose secrets
- SHA-256 evidence hashing: is the pre-image attack surface relevant? Is the hash chain verifiable end-to-end?
- Random generation: verify cryptographically random IDs are used everywhere an ID is security-relevant (no Math.random())
- Environment secrets: check .env handling — secrets must never be logged, must not appear in error messages or stack traces

### Network and Deployment
- HTTPS enforcement: verify TLS termination is enforced in all environments, not just local dev
- CORS configuration: review allowed origins, ensure wildcard CORS is not present in non-dev configs
- Rate limiting: in-memory rate limiter won't survive pod restarts or multi-replica deployment — needs Redis-backed distributed store
- Secrets in container images: verify no secrets baked into Dockerfile layers or K8s manifests

### Development and QA
- Security scanning: verify Snyk/npm audit covers all workspaces including apps/cockpit
- No pen-test or OWASP ZAP scan evidence — add to CI
- Security test cases: no automated tests verifying auth rejection (401/403 on missing/invalid tokens)

**Exit criteria**: All P0/P1 findings fixed and verified; auth rejection test suite added to CI; HTTPS enforcement documented; rate-limit distributed store in place or deferred with documented risk acceptance.

title: Implement evidence-first audit trail for approvals
description:
Build the evidence pipeline that ensures every approval interaction produces durable, auditable records. Every run must produce evidence you can audit — this is a core Portarium promise.

Evidence events to capture:
- approval_opened: who requested, what payload (hash), what policy evaluated to
- policy_evaluated: policy inputs, results, explanations, timestamp
- preview_generated: what was rendered for the approver, inputs used
- assigned: who was assigned, why (policy-driven or manual)
- decision_recorded: who decided, what they decided, rationale, what they saw (payload hash), timestamp
- run_unblocked: approval triggered downstream execution
- effects_applied: what actually happened post-approval
- rollback_executed: if rollback was needed, what was reverted

Requirements:
- Evidence objects are immutable, append-only
- Content-addressable: evidence references payload by hash so tampering is detectable
- Queryable: "show me everything that happened for approval X" timeline view
- Exportable: compliance teams can export evidence for external audit
- Linkage: evidence links to the exact approval payload snapshot, not mutable state
- Special handling for agent/robot requests: capture exactly what the human saw and decided

This is critical for regulated environments and for answering: "what did the human actually see and decide?"

title: Implement block-based presentation DSL for approval evidence
description:
Design and implement the typed block system that agents/workflows use to compose approval evidence. This is the "Notion-style blocks for approval evidence" concept — a strict schema-driven presentation layer that prevents arbitrary UI injection while enabling rich, domain-specific views.

Block types to implement:
- SummaryBlock: human-readable intent + objective + requestor
- PolicyBlock: SoD requirement, required approvers, policy explanations
- EffectsBlock: structured list of planned external effects (resources, operations, blast radius)
- DiffBlock: domain-specific diff rendering (table diff, JSON Patch, text tracked-changes)
- PreviewBlock: renderable output (image, PDF snapshot, MP4 demo, rendered HTML)
- SimulationBlock: dry-run output, predicted outcomes, rollback plan
- AIExplainBlock: model summary, confidence, key reasons + "show sources" links

Design constraints:
- Each block has a strict TypeScript schema; agents can only supply content matching the schema
- Blocks reference evidence payloads by hash/ID (content-addressable)
- Agents choose which blocks to include and in what order, but only from allow-listed set
- Agents can propose content but never execution (no arbitrary HTML/JS)
- Rendering is deterministic from block data — same data always produces same view
- JSON Patch (RFC 6902) as universal baseline for "what changed" representation

title: Implement security controls for agent-supplied approval content
description:
Implement the security boundary that prevents agents from injecting arbitrary UI/code through approval payloads while still allowing rich content presentation.

Threat model:
- Agents supply untrusted strings, rich text, URLs, images, videos
- Malicious or buggy agents could attempt XSS, data exfiltration, privilege escalation
- Agent-authored "layouts" could create misleading presentations that trick approvers

Security controls:
- Default to framework escaping + strict encoding/sanitisation for all agent-supplied content
- Restrict escape hatches: no direct DOM injection, no dangerouslySetInnerHTML for agent content
- Rich text sanitisation: allowlisted HTML tags/attributes only (no script, no event handlers)
- Strict Content Security Policy (CSP): reduce blast radius of any injection — no inline scripts, restricted connect-src
- URL validation: agent-supplied URLs must be allowlisted or proxied
- Image/media: proxy through Portarium CDN, no direct external loads (prevents tracking pixels, SSRF)
- Block schema validation: agent-supplied blocks must pass strict TypeScript schema validation before rendering
- Agents can propose content but never execution

Testing:
- XSS test suite against all block renderers with adversarial inputs
- CSP violation monitoring and alerting
- Fuzzing agent-supplied block content against schema validators

title: Architecture: replace in-memory stub defaults with fail-fast guards in bootstrap
description: From report-31 bead-8lup. Blocked by bead-lh3q (validate task). The control plane bootstrap uses in-memory or empty stub stores by default, meaning a deployment that omits required store configuration ships a silently non-functional system. Every store registration that defaults to an in-memory stub must instead throw a clear startup error unless explicitly configured for dev/test mode via an environment variable. Scope: (1) Audit the composition root / bootstrap file; list every store with a default in-memory implementation. (2) Add a startupGuard() helper that checks required env vars and throws a structured ConfigurationError with a helpful message if any required store is not configured. (3) Add a DEV_STUB_STORES=true env var that must be explicitly set to allow stubs (default off in production). (4) Add a startup integration test that confirms the process exits non-zero if required stores are not configured. Acceptance criteria: app fails to start with clear error if required stores are missing config; DEV_STUB_STORES gate is documented in .env.local.example; startup test in CI.
close_reason: Added store-bootstrap-gate.ts with checkStoreBootstrapGate(). Bootstrap throws FATAL if no Postgres config and DEV_STUB_STORES≠true. DEV_STUB_STORES=true allowed only in dev/test NODE_ENV. 11 unit tests. README documents the requirement. control-plane.test.ts updated to set DEV_STUB_STORES=true.

description: From report-27 bead-cyut. Blocked by bead-o0d3. Pack resolver and SOD evaluator have zero test coverage — these are core business logic. See validate task for confirmed scope.

title: Research Integration: Core CS Foundations (report-25)
description:
Epic to systematically integrate findings from docs/research/report-25.md — a review of core computer science foundations as applied in Portarium: programming fundamentals, OOP quality, data structures, algorithms, OS fundamentals (concurrency, I/O), and computing ethics context.

**Report summary**: Portarium is structured as a layered hexagonal/ports-and-adapters system with a clean split between control-plane (HTTP API + governance boundary) and execution-plane (worker behaviour, optional Temporal loop). The report evaluates how well foundational CS principles are applied: SOLID adherence, abstraction quality, appropriate data structure choices, algorithmic complexity, concurrency model soundness, and ethical computing considerations.

**Scope**: Full read → validate → implement cycle. The CS foundations review is likely to surface refactoring candidates and algorithmic improvements rather than entirely new features.

**Key themes from the report**:
- OOP & SOLID: identify classes/modules violating Single Responsibility, Open/Closed, or Dependency Inversion; map against the current layer structure
- Data structures: verify correct structure choices in hot paths (pack resolver, SOD evaluation, rate-limiter — maps vs arrays vs sets)
- Algorithms: review time complexity of key domain operations; flag any O(n²) patterns on lists that could grow large
- Concurrency: review async/await usage, identify any unhandled promise rejection risks, check for race conditions in multi-step workflows
- OS fundamentals: I/O patterns (buffered vs streaming), file descriptor management, signal handling in the worker process
- Ethics context: fairness considerations in approval workflows, audit trail completeness, bias surface in policy evaluation

**Exit criteria**: All child beads closed or deferred; a docs/adr/ entry covers any significant algorithmic or concurrency architecture decisions made as a result.

title: Local schema bootstrap — create tables/indexes + deterministic reset command
description: Local Postgres is running is not enough; you need guaranteed schema and deterministic reset. Deliverables: migration runner that applies all schema (tables, indexes, constraints) on first boot, reset command that drops and recreates (for dev iteration), idempotent apply (safe to re-run), integration with dev:seed workflow. Must work both for bare-metal Postgres and Compose-managed Postgres.

title: Local auth story — dev-only token mode or bundled OIDC/JWKS provider
description: Protected routes return 401 when auth config is absent, structurally preventing most API usage and Cockpit connection. Cockpit accepts bearer token via VITE_PORTARIUM_API_BEARER_TOKEN or localStorage. Options: (a) bundled Keycloak/Dex in Compose auth profile with pre-seeded users, or (b) dev-only token mode that bypasses JWKS validation in local dev. Either way, the local-first workflow must include how to mint or provide a token deterministically. This is a functional blocker for all real local API usage.

title: Local-First Developer Experience — one-command seeded stack
description:
Tracks the missing DX work to achieve a robust local-first developer experience. Currently Portarium supports a multi-step local run (Compose + separate runtime commands), but lacks:

- Single-command boot to "system usable" state
- Predictable persistence (schema present, data survives restarts, reset is explicit)
- Predictable auth (local OIDC or dev-only auth bypass)
- Smokeable E2E scenario (governed run producing evidence)

Existing bead-0733 covers the seed command itself; this epic covers the surrounding infrastructure (Compose profiles, auth, schema, DevContainer, smoke tests) that make bead-0733 actually work end-to-end.

Target: `npm run dev:all` → everything running, seeded, Cockpit connectable, one governed run demonstrable.
